qas.question: Why is the Pekin duck unfavorable in the western world?
What common variety of poultry in the west is not found in the east?

context: It is widely agreed that the <a0_0><b5_0>mallard (Anas platyrhynchos)<b5_0/> is the ancestor of all breeds of domestic duck (with the exception of the Muscovy duck<a0_0/> (Cairina moschata), which is not closely related to other ducks). Ducks are farmed mainly for their meat, eggs, and down. As is the case with chickens, <a1_0><b6_0>various breeds have been developed, selected for egg-laying ability, fast growth, and a well-covered carcase<b6_0/>.<a1_0/> The most common commercial breed in the United Kingdom and the United States is the <a2_0><b7_0>Pekin duck<b7_0/><a2_0/>, which <a3_0><b8_0>can lay 200 eggs a year and can reach a weight of 3.5 kg (7.7 lb) in 44 days<b8_0/><a3_0/>. In the Western world, ducks are not as popular as chickens, because the latter produce larger quantities of white, lean meat and are easier to keep intensively, making the price of chicken meat lower than that of duck meat. While popular in haute cuisine, duck appears less frequently in the mass-market food industry. However, things are different in the East. <a4_0><b9_0>Ducks<b9_0/> are more popular there than chickens and are mostly still herded in the traditional way and selected for their ability to find sufficient food in<a4_0/> harvested rice fields and other wet environments.
